3.learning_goal: Machine Learning Foundations: In this unit, students will learn to distinguish when ML is appropriate, match real-world problems to ML task types, define features and labels as signals, describe models as functions within the end-to-end ML workflow, avoid common pitfalls like overfitting and data leakage, and apply core data-preprocessing steps including loading tabular data, train/test splitting, handling missing values, encoding categories, and scaling features.

chapters.title: Foundations of Machine Learning Thinking
chapters.learning_goals: Build an intuitive understanding of what machine learning is (and isn’t), how to choose appropriate ML task types, and how data, labels, and features act as signals for models. Practice mapping real-world problems into ML formulations and deciding when to use ML versus traditional rule-based approaches.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What ML Is (and Isn’t)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand machine learning in contrast to rule-based systems; Identify problems that are appropriate for ML; Distinguish ML from traditional programming logic

lessons.title: ML Task Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify the main machine learning task types: classification, regression, and clustering; Understand how these task types relate to supervised learning (classification, regression) and unsupervised learning (clustering); Match real-world problems to the correct ML task and learning type (supervised vs. unsupervised); Understand why choosing the correct task type is a critical step before selecting a model or evaluation metric

lessons.title: Data and Labels
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish labeled vs unlabeled data; Identify input features and target variables; Understand how labels guide supervised learning

lessons.title: Features as Signals
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define features as model inputs; Identify raw vs derived features; Understand why feature quality impacts model performance

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML or Traditional Logic?
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will distinguish when a problem is better solved with traditional rule-based programming versus machine learning. Output: A completed worksheet or quiz where each scenario is labeled as “ML” or “Rule-based” with a short justification.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Matching Problems to ML Task Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will correctly match real-world problems to classification, regression, or clustering and to supervised vs unsupervised learning. Output: A filled-in matching table where each scenario is assigned an ML task type and learning type.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie Genre Classifier
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will identify features, labels, and ML task type from a small “movie recommendation” story. Output: A simple text-based description listing input features, the target label, and whether this is classification, regression, or clustering.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Sales Forecast
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will practice mapping a business question (predicting cafe sales) into features, target, and ML task type. Output: A short written “problem specification” that defines the ML task, features, label, and whether it’s supervised or unsupervised.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Features as Signals in a Music App
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will distinguish raw vs derived features and explain how each could act as a signal for a music recommendation problem. Output: A table or bullet list categorizing features as raw/derived with a one-line explanation of why each might help a model.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: From Rules to Machine Learning
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to describe machine learning models as functions, distinguish clearly between training and prediction, and use correct ML workflow vocabulary from data collection through evaluation and deployment. They will apply these ideas in simple, concrete scenarios (pricing, spam filtering, forecasting) and compare rule-based systems with learned models to understand how models generalize beyond memorized rules.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Training vs Prediction
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe what happens during model training; Understand how trained models make predictions; Identify when a model is “learning” vs “using knowledge”

lessons.title: Models as Functions
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe a model as a function mapping inputs to outputs; Compare simple rule logic to learned decision boundaries; Understand why models generalize instead of memorizing

lessons.title: ML Workflow Overview
lessons.learning_outcomes: Outline the full ML workflow from data to prediction; Identify where data prep, training, and evaluation fit; Use correct ML vocabulary to describe each step

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Training vs Prediction Timeline
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will sequence and label the steps where a model learns versus where it uses learned knowledge. Output: A completed timeline or flow diagram that clearly marks “training” and “prediction” phases for a simple ML use case.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: House Price Function
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will represent a simple model as a function that maps house features to a price and contrast it with fixed rules. Output: A short pseudo-code or simple Python-like function that takes a few numeric inputs and returns a predicted price.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Email Spam Filter Function
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will describe an ML spam filter as a function and identify inputs, outputs, and decision boundary intuition. Output: A text description or pseudo-code function that takes email attributes as input and outputs “spam” or “not spam” with a brief explanation of the decision boundary.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: ML Workflow for a Taxi Fare App
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will outline the end-to-end ML workflow for predicting taxi fares from raw trip data. Output: A step-by-step workflow document labeling data collection, cleaning, feature selection, training, evaluation, and prediction.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Weather Prediction Workflow Cards
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will correctly order shuffled workflow “cards” to build a coherent ML pipeline for predicting tomorrow’s temperature. Output: An ordered list of steps (with your chosen numbering) that shows the correct ML workflow sequence.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Rule-Based vs Learned Model Comparison
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will compare a simple rule-based decision system with a learned model for a loan approval scenario and explain how the model generalizes. Output: A short comparison table or paragraph explaining differences in behavior between the rule system and the learned model on several example applicants.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building Trustworthy ML Foundations
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to load and explore tabular data, perform reliable train/test splits, and recognize common ML pitfalls like overfitting, data leakage, and unrealistic evaluation so you can trust your model results.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Common ML Pitfalls
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify data leakage and why it breaks evaluation; Understand overfitting in intuitive terms; Recognize unrealistic performance expectations

lessons.title: Loading Tabular Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load datasets using pandas; Inspect rows, columns, and data types; Identify feature columns and targets

lessons.title: Train / Test Split
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why test data must be held out; Split data using scikit-learn; Describe how splits affect evaluation trustworthiness

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spotting ML Pitfalls in a Story
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will identify overfitting, data leakage, and unrealistic evaluation practices in a narrative case study. Output: A marked-up story or bullet list where each pitfall is named, underlined (or noted), and briefly explained.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Loading Cafe Sales Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will load a small tabular dataset with pandas, inspect its structure, and identify features and target. Output: A short script that reads a CSV, prints head(), info(), and lists which columns are features vs the target.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music Streams Dataset Exploration
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will practice loading a music streaming dataset and exploring rows, columns, and data types to prepare for modeling. Output: A script that loads the dataset, prints basic statistics, and outputs a summary of numeric vs categorical columns.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Train / Test Split for House Prices
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will perform a train/test split using scikit-learn and explain why the split improves trust in evaluation. Output: A script that loads a toy house-price dataset, splits it into train and test sets, and prints the shapes of each subset.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Train / Test Split for Customer Churn
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will apply train/test splitting to a customer churn dataset and verify that the target distribution is similar across splits. Output: A script that splits the data and prints value_counts() of the target in train and test sets for comparison.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Evaluating Overfitting Intuitively
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will simulate overfitting by comparing performance on training vs test data and interpret what the gap means. Output: A script that trains a simple model on tabular data, prints accuracy (or error) on both train and test sets, and outputs a short text interpretation of the results.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Preparing Data for Machine Learning
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to clean and transform raw data by handling missing values, encoding categorical features, and scaling numeric variables, and then combine these steps into practical preprocessing pipelines ready for real-world ML tasks.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Handling Missing Values
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify missing data in datasets; Apply simple imputation strategies; Explain tradeoffs of different approaches

lessons.title: Encoding Categories
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify categorical vs numeric features; Encode categorical variables for ML models; Explain why models require numeric inputs

lessons.title: Scaling Numeric Features
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain feature scale and why it matters; Apply basic scaling techniques; Identify models sensitive to feature scale

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Handling Missing Values in Housing Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will detect missing values in a housing dataset and apply simple imputation strategies such as mean and median. Output: A script that prints missing-value counts per column, applies imputation, and shows the cleaned dataset’s summary.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Customer Records Imputation
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will choose appropriate imputation strategies for different types of cafe customer fields (numeric vs categorical) and implement them. Output: A script that fills missing ages with a numeric strategy and missing categories (like “membership_tier”) with a categorical strategy, then prints before/after comparisons.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Encoding Categories in a Movie Dataset
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will identify categorical features in a movie dataset and apply one-hot encoding to make them numeric. Output: A script that selects categorical columns, applies one-hot encoding, and prints the transformed feature matrix shape and sample rows.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Encoding Categories in a Shopping Cart
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will transform product categories and payment types into numeric encodings suitable for ML models. Output: A script that encodes these categorical fields and prints the mapping or resulting encoded columns for inspection.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Scaling Features for a Fitness App
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will apply feature scaling (e.g., standardization or min-max scaling) to numeric fitness metrics and compare before/after ranges. Output: A script that scales features like steps, heart rate, and workout duration, then prints descriptive statistics before and after scaling.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Scaling and Encoding Pipeline for Taxi Fares
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will build a preprocessing pipeline that handles missing values, encodes categories, and scales numeric features for a taxi fare prediction task. Output: A script that constructs and fits a scikit-learn ColumnTransformer or Pipeline and outputs the transformed feature array shape and a few sample transformed rows.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

4.learning_goal: Supervised to Unsupervised ML: In this unit, students will build, evaluate, and compare linear and tree-based supervised models (for classification and regression), practice cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning to control overfitting and improve generalization, and apply core unsupervised techniques like K-Means clustering and PCA to explore and segment unlabeled data.

chapters.title: Supervised Learning: Classification, Regression, and Metrics
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to build and evaluate basic supervised learning models for both classification and regression, using Logistic and Linear Regression. Understand and apply core evaluation metrics (accuracy, precision, recall, F1, MAE, MSE/RMSE, R²) in practical scenarios to choose appropriate models and metrics for real-world problems.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: First Supervised Model - Logistic Regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain binary classification problems; Train a Logistic Regression model end-to-end; Explain predicted probabilities vs predicted classes; Explain why accuracy alone is not enough for model evaluation

lessons.title: Classification Metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Calculate and interpret accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score; Read and interpret a confusion matrix; Re-evaluate a Logistic Regression model using different metrics; Explain how metric choice depends on the problem context

lessons.title: Linear Regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain numeric prediction tasks; Train a Linear Regression model; Interpret predictions vs actual values; Explain regression error intuitively as distance from the true value

lessons.title: Regression Metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Calculate MAE, MSE/RMSE, and R²; Explain what each metric reveals about model errors; Compare regression models using appropriate metrics

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Email spam filter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Train and evaluate a Logistic Regression model for binary classification on an email spam vs. ham dataset, interpreting predicted probabilities and predicted classes. Output: A script that loads email features, trains a logistic regression spam filter, prints predicted probabilities and classes for new emails.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Medical test classifier metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use a confusion matrix to calculate and interpret accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score for a medical test classifier, and discuss which metric matters most in this context. Output: A script that takes model predictions and true labels, prints a confusion matrix and computed metrics, and highlights which metric to prioritize.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: House price regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: Train a Linear Regression model to predict house prices from features and interpret prediction errors as distances from the true values. Output: A script that fits a linear regression model, prints sample predictions vs actual prices, and shows residuals for each example.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe revenue forecast metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compute MAE, MSE/RMSE, and R² for a cafe’s daily revenue prediction model and compare how each metric reflects model performance. Output: A script that takes true and predicted revenues, calculates MAE, MSE, RMSE, and R², and prints a short comparison summary.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Model selection for loan approval
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare a Logistic Regression classifier and a Linear Regression-based threshold model for loan approval, using both classification and regression metrics to decide which is more appropriate. Output: A script that trains both models, evaluates them with relevant metrics, and prints a simple recommendation of which model to use and why.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Tree-Based Models and Model Validation
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to build and interpret tree-based models and their ensembles (Random Forests, Gradient Boosting), compare them to linear models, and understand their strengths and limitations. Develop a solid grasp of overfitting, generalization, and validation techniques (including cross-validation) through both conceptual discussion and hands-on practice.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Tree-Based Models
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain decision trees at a conceptual level; Train a tree-based classifier; Compare linear vs non-linear models; Discuss strengths and limitations of tree-based approaches

lessons.title: Ensembles
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain ensemble methods such as Random Forest and Gradient Boosting at a high level; Explain why ensembles are commonly used in practice; Build intuition for why combining models often improves performance

lessons.title: Overfitting, Generalization & Validation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify signs of overfitting and underfitting; Compare train vs test performance; Explain the bias-variance tradeoff; Explain cross-validation conceptually; Compare a single train/test split vs multiple folds

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Loan decision tree
lessons.learning_outcomes: Train and interpret a decision tree classifier for loan approvals, comparing its behavior and decision boundaries conceptually to Logistic Regression. Output: A script that trains a decision tree, prints its depth and feature importances, and shows example decisions for new applicants.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Customer churn random forest
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a Random Forest classifier for customer churn and discuss why an ensemble of trees can outperform a single tree. Output: A script that trains a random forest, reports accuracy and feature importances, and predicts churn probabilities for sample customers.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Gradient boosting credit risk
lessons.learning_outcomes: Train a gradient boosting classifier on a simplified credit risk dataset and compare its performance and behavior to a single decision tree. Output: A script that fits a gradient boosting model, evaluates it on a test set, and prints side-by-side metrics versus a baseline tree.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie rating overfitting check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Diagnose overfitting and underfitting on a movie rating prediction task by comparing train vs test performance for models of different complexity. Output: A script that trains multiple models (e.g., shallow vs deep trees), prints train/test scores, and flags where overfitting occurs.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cross-validation comparison
lessons.learning_outcomes: Conceptually and programmatically compare a single train/test split to k-fold cross-validation on a classification problem to understand variance in performance estimates. Output: A script that runs both a single split and k-fold cross-validation, printing all scores and their average and standard deviation.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Overfitting and validation quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce understanding of overfitting, generalization, bias-variance tradeoff, and cross-validation through a written quiz and scenario-based questions (no coding). Output: A completed quiz document where model behaviors are identified as overfitting/underfitting, and appropriate validation strategies are matched to scenarios.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Model Evaluation, Tuning, and Unsupervised Learning
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to evaluate models with cross-validation, tune hyperparameters using grid and randomized search, and distinguish hyperparameters from learned parameters. Develop an understanding of when and how to use unsupervised learning methods for exploratory analysis and real-world, label-free scenarios.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Cross-Validation Basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain cross-validation conceptually; Use cross-validation to estimate performance; Compare a single split vs multiple folds

lessons.title: Hyperparameters and Search
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define hyperparameters vs learned parameters; Use GridSearchCV or RandomizedSearchCV; Interpret tuning results responsibly

lessons.title: Unsupervised Learning
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain how unsupervised learning differs from supervised learning; Identify use cases without labels; Describe exploratory ML goals

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cross-validation for house prices
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use k-fold cross-validation to estimate the performance of a house price regression model and compare the stability of scores across folds. Output: A script that runs k-fold cross-validation on a regression model and prints fold-wise scores and their mean and variance.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fold comparison for spam classifier
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare a single train/test split to multiple-fold cross-validation for a spam classifier and interpret why the cross-validated estimate may be more reliable. Output: A script that computes accuracy for a single split and for k-fold CV, printing and comparing the results.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Grid search for tree depth
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use GridSearchCV to tune a decision tree classifier’s key hyperparameters (e.g., max_depth, min_samples_split) and interpret the best parameters and score. Output: A script that runs grid search, prints the best hyperparameters, best score, and a brief table of results.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Randomized search for forest
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply RandomizedSearchCV to tune a Random Forest classifier and understand tradeoffs between search breadth, runtime, and performance. Output: A script that performs randomized search over a parameter distribution, prints the best configuration, and compares it to a default model.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Hyperparameter vs parameter identification
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish hyperparameters from learned parameters by inspecting model attributes and documenting which values are set before training vs learned from data. Output: A script that trains a model, prints selected hyperparameters and learned coefficients, and writes a short textual summary.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Unsupervised learning scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world problems that are suitable for unsupervised learning and match them to appropriate unsupervised techniques conceptually. Output: A written exercise where scenarios (e.g., customer segmentation, anomaly detection) are matched to unsupervised methods and labeled vs unlabeled contexts are explained.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to apply K-Means clustering and PCA to segment data, choose and evaluate the number of clusters, and visualize high-dimensional datasets in 2D. Develop practical skills by implementing clustering workflows on realistic scenarios like customer behavior, app usage, and image data.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: K-Means Clustering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain how K-Means groups data; Train a clustering model; Interpret clusters at a high level

lessons.title: Choosing Number of Clusters
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain the role of k in clustering; Use simple heuristics to choose cluster count; Interpret clustering tradeoffs

lessons.title: PCA for Visualization
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain dimensionality reduction intuitively; Apply PCA to reduce features; Visualize high-dimensional data in 2D

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Customer segmentation with K-Means
lessons.learning_outcomes: Train a K-Means clustering model to segment customers based on purchase behavior and interpret the resulting clusters at a high level. Output: A script that runs K-Means, prints cluster centers, and assigns each customer to a segment.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music listener clustering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply K-Means to group music app users by listening patterns and summarize how each cluster’s behavior differs. Output: A script that clusters users, prints cluster sizes and average feature values per cluster, and labels clusters with simple descriptive names.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Choosing k for cafe visitors
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use heuristics such as the elbow method and simple silhouette inspection to choose the number of clusters (k) for cafe visitor data. Output: A script that trains K-Means for multiple k values, plots or prints inertia/silhouette scores, and suggests a reasonable k.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cluster tradeoff exploration
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explore the tradeoff between too few and too many clusters by comparing cluster compactness and interpretability across different k values. Output: A script that fits K-Means with several k values and prints metrics and brief textual interpretations for each.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: PCA visualization of digits
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply PCA to reduce a high-dimensional dataset (e.g., handwritten digits) to 2D and visualize the data points colored by label. Output: A script that performs PCA, generates 2D coordinates, and produces a scatter plot showing how classes are separated.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: PCA and clustering combination
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine PCA for dimensionality reduction with K-Means clustering to visualize and interpret clusters in a 2D space. Output: A script that runs PCA, applies K-Means on the reduced data, and plots the clusters in 2D with different colors for each cluster.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions
